Santorum conveniently left out a portion of the President's comments: "When I speak about higher education we're not just talking about a four-year degree," he said. "We're talking about somebody going to a community college and getting trained for that manufacturing job that now is requiring somebody walking through the door, handling a million-dollar piece of equipment. And they can't go in there unless they've got some basic training beyond what they received in high school."
The problem with these candidates is how easy it is for them to lie or distort facts to suit their agenda. In fact, lying has become so prevalent one has to wonder if it is a strategy since most Americans will not check their statements for accuracy. The truth is: lies stick. They are a very effective political tool.
I watch Romney is his dirty blue jeans and have to think, who is he trying to fool. Here is a man worth approximately $250 million and probably would not be caught dead on the street in jeans if he were not running for office and tying to attract the blue collar worker. The more these candidates speak, they more they reveal themselves as phony. Their promises that they are going to somehow move this country to some sort of Camelot is B.S. It is tales told by politicians full of sound and fury signifying nothing.

The unions that Willard (Mitt) Romney wants to so badly weaken to the point of death (aka Scott Walker, Maine's Governor Le Page, and John Kaisich) are, by far, to fight for the kind of working conditions and pay levels not so anti-family stability. There is no way that a business person, whose sole modus operandi has been to operate a corporation "chop shop" named Bain Capital can or well provide improvement for the lives of most of us!
If Blue Collar workers skilled or unskilled want a job they will have to move  to China that's where the Suits have moved all the jobs to!

The reality is despite all the theatrics by Santorum, most blue collar workers, ranging from unskilled to skilled workers, get their jobs through the efforts of white collar entrepreneurs or corporate managers in suits and ties.  Even the former blue collar worker who managed to start and build his own business, with some exceptions transitions to the roll of a manager, business proprietor or officer.   Santorum's attack on Obama for his support of college being available to all Americans, calling that elitist, was somewhere between mindless and phony.  The fact is that the world we now live in and that of the future increasingly demands that workers have some sort of skill set beyond a high school diploma.  Right now unemployment for non-college graduates is double that of college graduates.  Santorum's attack on college education was simply pandering to the crowd.  America must offer Americans a diverse menu of post high school education ranging from trade schools, community college or two year degrees geared to special skills, traditional four year college degrees, as well as graduate and other advanced degrees.   America will need people with such training to provide the technicians and operators of the technologies that will increasingly be needed in fields like health care, communications, maintenance of motor vehicles, homes and infrastructure, information technology, along with electricians and other traditional skilled workers.

I agree that a larger group from the industry should have been invited. Otherwise it appears that the Senator is favoring publicly traded leading technology companies in exchange for "fill in the blank."

As for FaceBook They are always having issues regarding privacy. As many people have stated you may be able to remedy by not allowing geo location tracking on your device. Additionally you determine what is public, private and hopefully FaceBook doesn't run off with your data, photos, etc...

As the internet enabled connected mobile devices are more widely used we will see more problems. One would expect a reasonable level of security on iPhones and other devices.

Do you think consumers would be willing to pay to own & manage their own facebook style connected blog?

One would think a group of companies would have already found a way for consumers to pay for securing their mobile devices. Yeah I talking to you Telco and security apps companies.

Well, I am sure there was anti-Catholic bigotry afoot in the U.S. of 1928, but let us remember that execept for Cleveland and Wilson, no Protestant Democrat had been elected since 1856.  Moreover, Hoover was an early graduate of Stanford University, an successful engineer, a humanitarian (post WWI relief etc.), a member of the president's cabinet, married to a brilliant woman, a moderate, and running during a boom (well, maybe a Wall Street bubble).  So, I always thought it was a bit much to credit bigotry to Hoover's win.  Of course he became a bete noire for the Democrats for 20 years.  Candidate Kennedy was correct to try to defuse the religious issue in 1960, but perhaps it was a straw man.  The Roosevelt-Truman-Stevenson Democrats I knew liked what Kennedy said about many things, didn't give a damn that he was Catholic, but were concerned about the reputation of his father for being an appeaser of Hitler and being somewhat unfriendly to Jews, not to put too fine a point on it, but a Harvard man,Joe, should have known better. Is there any evidence that traditional Democratic voters were about to desert the party to vote Republican?   I really don't know.  I do know that  Kennedy never said that religion should be banished from the public square -- that is a straw man set up by Senator Santorum.  When asked about the Supreme Court decision banning enforced daily prayer in PUBLIC schools, Kennedy said something like:  Ah, they could pray at home or in church.  Precisely.

I'm sorry, but no. The "ask not what your country can do ..." speech had nothing to do with Kennedy's election -- that was his inaugural address.

Not all us really approve of that idea, anyway. I agree that people should seek to serve others, not merely take from others; nevertheless, as Jefferson said, countries and governments are instituted to serve our interests, not the other way around. Excessive emphasis on "serving your country" is the tool of war mongers; Kennedy occasionally came close to being one of those.

There is another way to sequester carbon garnered by plants. Check into biochar, which has multiple advantages and functions, carbon sequestration being one of major ones. It also conditions and enhances soil, can remediate toxic sites, and be a non-food source of biofuel.

All in all, about 30 percent of plant-waste carbon can be sequestered (at least a billion tons per year) using only intrinsic energy and with little or no carbon output.

There is a very basic introduction to the topic on my web site, and a lot more on the International Biochar Initiative's site.

Thank you for a beautifully written column and the inclusion of the video of John Kennedy's speech. I was raised Catholic and remember only the palpable excitement on my mother's part when this elegant and well spoken man was elected. There was an incredible sadness on his passing, I remember Americans coming together to mourn the loss of a great man.

When I listened to his speech, I am left wondering why anyone would oppose a separation between a person's religious views and as John Kennedy stated, what is the best interest of the country. He was fearless and spoke honestly and with integrity, I see no one on the world stage of today who can communicate as effectively as he.
